newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan says "very delighted" by U.S. missile deal.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan says "very delighted" by U.S. missile deal.

text.p: Taiwan said on Tuesday it welcomed a U.S. move to award a missile contract to the island, hailing the deal as part of Washington's efforts to maintain peace between the island and its giant neighbour, China.
"The foreign ministry is very delighted about the contract," state-run Central News Agency quoted foreign ministry spokesman Peter Cheng as saying.

The U.S. Army announced without elaboration that it had awarded the US$63 million contract to Boeing Defence and Space Group, Missiles and Space Division, in Huntsville, Alabama, to produce 74 Avenger fire units for Taiwan.
"We believe the United States wants to maintain the stability across the Taiwan Strait, so it provided us with defensive weapons," Cheng said.
Taiwan's military has kept a low-profile over the deal in an apparent attempt to prevent feared protests from rival China.
"It is inappropriate to discuss any aspects of military deployment, such as the use of military personnel or artillery," spokesman Kung Fan-ting told reporters.
Taiwan and China have been rivals since the Nationalist government lost the Chinese civil war to the communists and fled into exile to Taiwan in 1949.
Since then, Beijing has regarded Taiwan as a renegade province not entitled to foreign ties and vows to retake the island by force if Taipei opts for independence.
The Army's announcement on the weapons came just days before a relations-mending trip to Washington by a delegation headed by Chinese Defence Minister Chi Haotian.

General Chi and a 20-member senior delegation from China's defence and foreign ministries is due to arrive in the United States on Thursday for a two-week visit at the invitation of Defence Secretary William Perry.
The Avenger is a mobile anti-aircraft defence missile system that can launch eight Stinger missiles from two reloadable pods.
The U.S. Defence Department approved the Taiwan sale last summer, despite a warning from China's foreign ministry that it would cause "new damage" to improving U.S.-China relations.
On August 25, the Defence Department notified Congress of plans to sell Taiwan 1,299 Stinger missiles, launchers and other equipment, despite China's protest.
Despite switching diplomatic recognition to Beijing from Taipei in 1979, Washington reserves the right to provide Taiwan with defensive weapons.
Earlier this year, Beijing carried out a series of war games in waters off Taiwan intended to intimidate voters in the run-up to Taiwan's first-ever direct presidential election.
Taiwan also planned to buy 68 batteries of French Mistral missiles, but the deal has not yet been finalised, state-funded television reported.
Officials here said the Mistrals could theoretically work with the Avenger units with a small modification.
China strongly objects to military links between the island and foreign countries.
Taiwan has said the Avenger units and the Patriot anti-missile system, bought from U.S. defence giant Raytheon Co, would enter service in 1999, boosting the island's defences against China.
